STATE OF NEBRASKA Biennial Report OF THE Superintendent OF THE Girls' Training School GENEVA, NEBRASKA To the Governor and the Board of Control of State Institutions For the Period Ending June 30, 1923

3 FOREWORD To His Excellency, the Governor : The Board of Control herewith transmits the Fifth Biennial Report of the State Institutions of Nebraska for the period ending June 30, 1923. The biennium formerly ended on November 30 of each even-numbered year, but this date was changed by an act of the legislature, so that this report really covers a period of thirty-one months from December 1, 1920, to June 30, 1923. During the period, no change has occurred in the personnel of the Board, but several changes have been made in the chief officers of institutions. Dr. Beverly A. Finkle, superintendent of the Orthopedic Hospital, Lincoln, Nebraska, resigned to enter private practice, and was succeeded on August 23, 1921, by Dr. J. H. Matthai. Miss Amy V. Stevens, who had been superintendent of the Home for Dependent Children, Lincoln, Nebraska, for a number of years, resigned on July 5, 1922, being succeeded by her sister, Miss Nellie Stevens. The latter served until February 19, 1923, when her resignation was received, and Miss Lena Driever was appointed to the position. We call attention with pride and pleasure to the fact that the report shows the institutions to have gone through the bien - nium without incurring any deficiencies; although the cost of living, and consequently the cost of supporting the state's depen - dents, has certainly not decreased since the appropriations were made for the biennium. Some improvements of a pcrmament character have been made at the various institutions during the period covered by this report. A hospital building, bakery and scullery have been erected at the Nebraska Institution for Feeble Minded, Beatrice, Nebraska ; a cottage for girls at the Girls' Training School, Geneva, Nebraska; a hospital building at the Soldiers and Sailors' Home, Burkett,

4 Nebraska ; a gymnasium building at the State Industrial School, Kearney, Nebraska; a hospital building at the Hospital for Tuberculous, Kearney, Nebraska ; a farm house and a barn at the Lincoln State Hospital, Lincoln, Nebraska ; a warehouse at the State Penitentiary, Lincoln, Nebraska ; a hospital building at the Soldiers and Sailors' Home, Milford, Nebraska; a kitchen building at the Norfolk State Hospital, Norfolk, Nebraska ; a main building at the State Reformatory for Women, York, Nebraska. These buildings were badly needed, and they will have to be -followed by others in the very near 'future if our wards are to be properly, efficiently and economically cared for. The legislature just past made provision for two or three buildings, but failed to see the necessity for several others that were urgently requested. Brief mention was made in the last report of the establishment of the Reformatory for Men at Lincoln, but the importance of the institution calls, we believe, for rather more extended notice. This institution was established as a result, primarily, of a wide recognition of the need of segregating young first-term offenders from more mature criminals. The legislature of 1921 authorized the establishment, therefore, of such an institution, making an initial approproation of $300,000. Of this sum the Board ex - pended $37,500 for 10 acres and a brick building known as the Hayward Military Academy, later buying about 152 acres of contiguous land for the sum of $49,531.25. This land is used for farming, stock raising, dairying, and intensive gardening. Various trades are taught such as tailoring, shoe repairing, carpentry and joinery, brick laying, electricity, automobile repairing, launder - ing, engineering, firing, and barbering. The manual labor about the institution is, of course, performed by the inmates, of which there are at this date 189. Mr. A. W. Miller, the superintendent, is doing much constructive work with the young men committed to his charge, and we believe the institution is amply justifying itself. The difficulty of employing the penitentiary inmates at suitable labor that does not conflict too much with the prerogatives of the free workers of our state, has been pretty well overcome. The state still operates the fibre furniture factory which has been at the prison for some years, and has also established relations with the Oberman Company by which shirts are made and disposed of with a minimum of competition with free labor.

7 Home for Dependent Children, Lincoln — Grand Total. 4,538,783.65 At its various institutions the state owns something over 4000 acres of land, of which in excess of 3500 are in farm and garden. About 800 acres are rented in addition. Details of operation are given in the reports from the several superintendents which are appended hereto. The health of the inmate population has been generally good during the past biennium. We are pleased to be able to report that no epidemic has broken out at any of the institutions, and our medical men have been able to cope with such sporadic cases of contagious disease as have appeared. In conclusion we wish to express our appreciation of the efforts of the officers and employees of the various institutions in striving to bring about a betterment of the living conditions of the wards under their care. We wish also to thank the Governor for his manifestations of interest and for his assistance in the work of this department, and we trust that he will continue his efforts to help us provide better means of caring for the wards of the state. 19 To the Governor and the Board of Control of State Institutions, Lincoln, Nebraska : It is with no small degree of pleasure that we review the work of the past two years. Although we have been somewhat handi - capped on account of insufficient means and lack of room, yet a great deal has been accomplished and these have been years of prosperity and progress. One of the things for which we feel most grateful and which we know is a step in the right direction is the beginning of the Cottage System. Nebraska was one of the few states whose school was on the old congregate plan, but we now have almost completed our first modern cottage. This cottage is of the old colonial type with plenty of windows, a large living room, with fire place and built-in book cases. This room is furnished with everything to give it the appearance and atmosphere of a real home. There is also a sewing-room, laundry, dining-room and well equipped kitchen. Each girl has her own room, provided with a good bed, rocker and dresser. To many it is the first taste of real comforts and home life. The occupants of this cottage will be chosen from our best girls, who have mani - fested a real desire to make the most of the opportunities which the state is giving them. They chose the name of Fanny Crosby for this cottage and they will be known as Crosby girls. Before entering this cottage a girl must read the life of Fanny Crosby and learn for what she stood, and take the following pledge: "I pledge my loyalty to the Girls' Training School. I promise to be worthy of the honor and responsibility given me in electing me a Crosby sister. I will perform my duties to the best of my ability. I promise to do all in my power to uphold the Ideals for which the School stands." The day will begin and close by singing one of Fanny Crosby's hymns. Could the tax payers of Nebraska realize the interest and appreciation the girls have manifested in this cottage, they would feel well repaid for the money spent.

20 Religious Training Sifnday mornings at eight o'clock the girls pass to the audi - torium where one hour is spent in the study of the International Sunday School lesson. At three in the afternoon one of the minis - ters from Geneva speaks to the girls, and at seven Christian Endeavor meetings are held in the different families. A leader is chosen from the girls and some very interesting meetings are held. The girls all take an active part. Last winter Professor Hendrickson of McPherson, Kansas, offered an illustrated copy of the Sermon on the Mount to every girl who would learn the entire Sermon, and one hundred eighty - rive girls signified their desire to do so. Of this number one hundred thirty-three learned it so well they could give it almost without mistake. Professor Hendrickson was so pleased with this that he gave each girl a copy of the Xew Testament. This is highly prized by each girl who received one. School Work One teacher was added to our force last year. This was a great help as she handled the lower grades, giving the other two teachers the sixth, seventh and eighth grades. In these grades we had one hundred girls, forty-eight being in the eighth grade, and not one in this grade failed to pass the county examination. One girl tied with the highest grade made in the county. Next year we hope to add another teacher, which will enable us to do some ninth and tenth grade work. The grades of the girls on parole attending school averaged from 92.5 to 97. Music We have an instructor who teaches piano and voice. There is no influence so effective in uniting the spirit of the girls as music. As they unite in song so they unite in thought. Three nights out of each week the girls gather in the auditorium and one hour is spent in singing good songs. Each night, after roll call, and the diffi - culties of the day have been straightened out, fifteen minutes are spent in singing in the different families before they retire. It is our aim never to put a girl to bed in an unhappy spirit, and nothing will take the place of singing in inducing the right frame of mind. Industrial Training We keep before us constantly the fact that in a very few years many of these girls will be in homes of their own and become

21 mothers of the coming generation. With this thought uppermost in our minds, we endeavor to train them for this responsibility. Everything that goes to make a well equipped house-keeper and home-maker is taught. The girls not only get the theory of all this work, hut the actual experience of planning and doing the work. Large quantities of fruit and vegetables are canned each year. The girls are always enthusiastic over this work. It never seems to grow old and each year they try to excel the class of the year before. Their best single day's work last year was canning 1234 cans of corn. The State University Extension Department has been a help to us. They send a representative to give us lectures and demonstrations whenever it is possible to do so. Work and Recreation All the outside work is done by the girls. They prepare the seed beds, and do the planting, cultivating and harvesting of all the crops. We have the reputation of having the fewest weeds and the best-kept barn lots in the neighborhood. During the past year, we have been able to do considerable fencing which has added a great deal to the appearance of the grounds, and has made it possible for us to better care for our poultry and stock. The girls helped with the building of the fences, digging the post holes and helping to set the posts. We have been fortunate in having a splendid woman to supervise such work. The school has a herd of Holstein cows, a fine drove of Hampshire hogs, and a flock of chickens, turkeys, ducks, geese and guineas. Raising and caring for all' these is a real pleasure for the girls. It is not "ail work and no play" at the school. There is a time for work and a time for play. Special picnics, wienie roasts, watermelon feeds, ball games and all kinds of races and games are enthusiastically entered into by the girls. The observance of all holidays is an established custom. Needs Our greatest need at this time is a parole officer, — someone who could devote her time to looking after the girls on parole Almost every girl leaving the school goes with higher ideals in life and fully determined to make good, but unless she has a proper place to go, with good environment and someone to advise and

22 4 encourage her, she often drifts back into her former life. If we had a good woman, someone with experience in dealing with the unprivileged girl and who understands her and her problems, we feel sure that very few girls would fail to make good. In conclusion, to all who have in any way contributed to the success of our work, we desire to express our appreciation. To my co-workers, who have been loyal and faithful and have labored so willingly, I am most grateful. And to the members of the Board, I desire to express my deepest gratitude for kindness, wise counsel and loyal support at all times. Respectfully submitted, LENA E. WARD, Superintendent
